name: South Asian Music
description: Traditional and modern regional music of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka, which culturally have close connections.

children.name: Adhunik geet
children.description: Nepali popular music which fuses elements of light Hindustani Classical Music, Ghazal and Western music.

children.name: Baila
children.description: Sri Lankan popular music and dance genre that is believed to have its origins in Afro-Portuguese performance traditions brought to Sri Lanka during the Portuguese occupation.

children.name: Balochi Music
children.description: Music of the Baloch people.

children.name: Bhajan
children.description: Song-based form of devotional music within Dharmic religions, with lyrical themes having an emphasis on deep adoration for a deity.

children.name: Bhangra
children.description: Percussion-driven blend of Punjabi Folk Music with modern Pop, with its name coming from a traditional folk dance celebrating the harvest.

children.name: Dek Bass
children.description: Prominent heavy, sustained bass tones, percussion derived from South Asian Music, and often high-pitched sound effects or samples; commonly played at extreme volumes in DJ/sound system competitions.

children.name: Dhol tasha
children.description: Energetic, dense rhythms played on the dhol and tasha drums, which the genre is named after.

children.name: Filmi
children.description: Music of films in the Indian subcontinent, representing the shared styles of the linguistically segregated industries in India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nepal.

children.name: Gaana
children.description: Style of Tamil music originating in northern Chennai's working-class communities, defined by fast-paced delivery and introspective lyrics often offering social commentary on everyday life.

children.name: Garba
children.description: Swinging rhythms and use of clapping/stomping; traditionally performed with the instruments dhol, dholak, tabla, harmonium, and naal, though newer productions can contain Electronic elements.

children.name: Ginan
children.description: Form of musical recitation sacred to Nizari Ismaili Muslims.

children.name: Goan Music
children.description: Music of Goa, a former Portuguese colony on the west coast of India, rooted in the traditions of its inhabitants.

children.name: Indian Pop
children.description: Commonly based out of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh and almost always sung in Hindi, Urdu or Bengali, implements South Asian Music in context of American and European Pop and Rock music.

children.name: Indo Jazz
children.description: Fuses the various musical traditions of the Indian subcontinent with jazzy musical structures.

children.name: Pop Ghazal
children.description: Employs traditional Ghazal's verse, meter, and poetic inclinations in a pop form.

children.name: Rigsar
children.description: Dominant form of popular music in Bhutan which broke traditions to move towards a more Western and Indian approach.

children.name: Sindhi Music
children.description: Music rooted in the traditions of the Sindhi people.

children.name: South Asian Classical Music
children.description: Meta-genre that covers the diverse forms of Classical Music from South Asia.

children.name: South Asian Folk Music
children.description: Meta-genre which covers all the Traditional Folk Music forms from South Asia.

children.name: Sufi Rock
children.description: Pakistani subgenre rooted in Sufi tradition, featuring South Asian instruments like the dhol, tabla, and sitar within a Rock band format with lyrics and imagery inspired by traditional Sufi poets.

children.name: Sufiana kalam
children.description: Classical music from Kashmir, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.

children.name: Vedic Chant
children.description: Sacred Hindu chants rooted in the ancient Vedas, and primarily recited as mantras, requiring strict precision and diligence.
